content: The candy and snack food industries are doing well right now, based on statistics released Tuesday at the Sweets and Snacks Expo. But you wouldn't know that from the share prices of publicly traded companies in the sector."Consumer staples in general are extremely out of favor," Edward Jones analyst Brittany Weissman said. "Consumer staples have significantly underperformed the broader market."IBD's confectionery industry group ranks near the bottom of 197 industry groups. It includes just four stocks: Mondelez International (MDLZ), Hershey (HSY), Tootsie Roll Industries (TR) and Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory (RMCF).Many makers of sweets and snacks are in IBD's packaged-food industry group, which ranks No. 161. It includes 29 stocks, among them Nestle (NSRGY), PepsiCo (PEP), General Mills (GIS), Kellogg (K), ConAgra Brands (CAG) and Hostess Brands (TWNK).Investors started rotating out of food stocks in mid-2016 in anticipation of rising interest rates, Weissman said.Amazon's (AMZN) acquisition of Whole Foods Market, announced in June 2017, added to the worries, she said.The Amazon-Whole Foods merger, completed in August 2017, led to large grocery sellers like Walmart (WMT) and Kroger (KR) gaining more negotiating power with manufacturers, she said. That's made it harder for food makers to pass on cost increases, such as rising grain and cocoa prices.Another factor hitting major candy and snack makers has been the rise of store brands. They include Kirkland Signature at Costco Wholesale (COST), Member's Mark at Walmart-owned Sam's Club and Wickedly Prime at Amazon.To combat these private-label products, the major candy and snack companies are focusing on product innovation to attract consumers. They're using new ingredients, different combinations, bold flavors and novel textures to entice customers.Many of these new products were on display at the annual Sweets and Snacks Expo, which ran Tuesday through Thursday in Chicago. The show had about 900 exhibiting companies and was expected to attract about 18,000 attendees.This year's Sweets and Snacks Expo is the biggest yet in terms of number of exhibitors and attendees, said Christopher Gindlesperger, vice president of public affairs and communications for the National Confectioners Association, which sponsors the show.Product trends among candy makers at this year's show include greater use of coconut and caramel in products, Gindlesperger said.Cocoa and chocolate producer Barry Callebaut is promoting its new ruby chocolate at the trade show. Introduced last September, it is the fourth type of chocolate after milk, dark and white. Made from the ruby cocoa bean, the pink chocolate has a "berry-fruitness and luscious smoothness," the Swiss firm said in a press release.Candy sales in the U.S. are expected to reach $25.3 billion in 2018, up from $24.9 billion in 2017, marketing and consulting firm IRI said at the show.Snack sales are seen hitting $42.5 billion in 2018, up from $41.1 billion in 2017."Consumers are still snacking," said Sally Lyons-Wyatt, executive vice president at IRI. "On average consumers are snacking over 2.5 times a day. Younger consumers actually snack more than that."Top growing categories in snacks include protein, fiber and energy snacks, she said. Consumers are also shifting more to crisps not made from potato or corn, she said. Consumers enjoy variety and are trying chips made from chickpeas, lentils, quinoa and other ingredients.Food companies are targeting millennials by offering products in smaller portion sizes suitable for snacking."It seems like almost anything can be a snack right now," Edward Jones' Weissman said. "You change the portion size and suddenly it's a snack. Everybody is focused on snacks. Yogurt went from breakfast to a snack. It's a much more crowded marketplace."RELATED:Amazon Widens Its Influence Even More And Takes A Bite Out Of SnacksCampbell, Hershey, Humana Lead Frenzy Of Year-End M&A Activity

Another chief executive fell victim to the slump in the U.S. packaged-food industry.Campbell Soup (CPB) CEO Denise Morrison, 64, abruptly stepped down Friday after a lackluster seven-year tenure at the helm of the company. She tried — and never managed — to move beyond canned soup to ignite sales growth as Americans change how they eat and shop. The shares plunged the most in almost two decades."They've had a rough go of it," said Michael Halen, an analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence. "The move into the fresh business has been problematic — they've had a lot of things that didn't work."Morrison will be replaced on an interim basis by Keith McLoughlin, a 61-year-old former CEO at Electrolux who has been a board member since 2016, Campbell said. The Camden, New Jersey-based company didn't say who will permanently succeed her, but last month promoted industry veteran Luca Mignini to chief operations officer.Whoever replaces Morrison will face the same challenges that have claimed the leaders of other Big Food companies like Kellogg (K) and Mondelez International (MDLZ). The stock, down 38% in the past two years, plunged an additional 11% to 34.94 on Friday as Campbell also gave a bleak full-year forecast. Campbell is suffering its biggest intraday loss since January 1999.Morrison, who has been with Campbell for 15 years, took over in 2011 and less than a year later Campbell agreed to buy Bolthouse Farms, a maker of fresh juice and salad dressing that also operated a carrot-farming business. The deal was seen as a way to push the canned soup company into fresher and more natural products, which are on trend with modern consumers. But the merger has been hampered by operational issues and a recall that battered results. Campbell has since been mired in a three-year sales slump.The stock said it will start a strategic review of its businesses, which will "take several months to complete." It plans to update investors on the outcome when it reports fourth-quarter results in late August.Campbell has been seeking other sources of growth as it grapples with the soup slowdown. In December, the company agreed to buy Snyder's-Lance in a bid to push deeper into salty snacks — a bright spot in the struggling packaged-food industry. That deal gives Campbell, which makes Goldfish crackers, brands such as Cape Cod potato chips and Snyder's pretzels.The recently promoted COO, Mignini, 55, joined Campbell in 2013. He had been running the snacks unit, and is now overseeing Campbell's soup business in addition to managing the expanded portfolio of snacks.

Shares of General Mills (GIS) sank Wednesday after the Cheerios and Yoplait maker delivered mixed results and lowered its growth outlook citing significant cost headwinds.General Mills' dive spread contagion through the packaged food sector, taking down shares of Kellogg (K), Kraft Heinz (KHC), Campbell Soup (CPB), J.M. Smucker Co. (SJM), ConAgra (CAG) and Mondelez (MDLZ). Kraft Heinz and Campbell Soup hit the sector last month on their weak quarterly reports.Shares of General Mills plunged 8.85% to 45.51 on the stock market today, hitting their lowest level in nearly five years. General Mills is by far the worst-performing stock on the S&P 500 index.They have tumbled since their Jan. 25 high of 60.69. Kellogg crashed 4%. Kraft Heinz lost 1.9%, hitting its worst levels since August 2015, while Campbell Soup sank 2.2%, reaching a 4-year low. Mondelez slid 0.8% and J.M. Smucker retreated 4.2%.Kellogg, J.M. Smucker, Campbell Soup and ConAgra all were among the S&P 500 index's worst-performers.The Minneapolis-based company reported adjusted quarterly profit grew 10% to 79 cents per share, meeting the Zacks Investment Research consensus estimate. Revenue ticked up 2% to $3.88 billion, just short of views for $3.89 billion. Organic net sales — stripping out the effect of currency movements, acquisitions and divestitures — were up 1%.Cost pressures are impacting the full-year outlook, said General Mills Chairman and CEO Jeff Harmening. General Mills cut its adjusted earnings growth forecast to flat to up 1% from up 3% to 4% earlier.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"Like the broader industry, we're seeing sharp increases in input costs, including inflation in freight and commodities," Harmening added. "Because of our improved volume performance, we're also incurring higher operational costs."Net sales for the North America retail segment rose 1% to $2.52 billion, thanks in large part to Canada. Yogurt and cereal sales fell in the U.S.Sales in the convenience stores and food service segment rose 3% to $460 million, driven by growth in frozen meals, cereal, and snacks.Europe and Australia sales grew 11% to $470 million, benefiting from favorable currency moves. Organic net sales slipped 1%.Asia and Latin America sales increased 3% to $435 million, also helped by foreign currency exchange. Organic net sales matched year-ago levels.  Asia markets saw higher sales, offsetting lower net sales across Latin America.General Mills said Wednesday its previously announced $8 billion acquisition of natural pet food brand Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) is expected to close before the end of fiscal 2018. Natural, wholesome and premium fare is in demand in pet food, as in human food, according to General Mills.Packaged food is under strain as private-label house brands as well as organic and natural offerings displace mainstream products on grocery shelves at the likes of Walmart (WMT) and Kroger (KR) and Amazon (AMZN)-owned Whole Foods.Walmart is General Mills' biggest customer, accounting for some 20% of sales.Packaged food companies have responded with cost cuts, including on marketing, to preserve profit margins, but that strategy is running out of steam. Kraft Heinz's latest results show the cost-cutting strategy is running out of steam.Blue Buffalo shares edged 0.3% lower Wednesday. Walmart rose 0.3%, Amazon dipped 0.3%. and Kroger added 0.2%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Forget Facebook: Why These 5 Chip Stocks Are Stock Market Bullish; S&P 500, Dow Jones Futures Await Fed Rate HikeThe Big Picture: Stock Bounce Leaves Much To Be DesiredNo. 1-Ranked IPO Stock Breaks Out, Expects Big Q1 Earnings GrowthThese 5 Top Stocks Stood Out MondayThese 3 China Nets Are Flashing This Bullish Signal; This 1 Has Earnings Due'China's Amazon' JD.com Has These Futuristic Projects In The Works

Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) skyrocketed Monday after the soft-drinks company agreed to a merger with privately held K-Cup maker Keurig Green Mountain,. Dr Pepper shareholders will get $103.75 a share cash plus hold 13% of the combined Keurig Dr Pepper.X Shares of Dr Pepper Snapple vaulted 22% to 117.07 on the stock market today. after rising as high as 126.65 intraday.Keurig Green Mountain was bought out by private equity firm JAB Holding in March 2016. JAB owns Panera Bread, Peet's Coffee, Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, Caribou Coffee and more.Keurig Dr Pepper would have combined 2017 annual revenues of approximately $11 billion, bringing together brands Dr Pepper, 7UP, Snapple, A&W, Mott's and Sunkist with the maker of Keurig single-serve coffee machines and K-cup pods. The companies expected $600 million in synergies on an annualized basis by 2021. Dr Pepper Snapple expects to pay its first-quarter ordinary dividend of $0.58 per share. At the close of the transaction, the company expects to deliver an annual dividend of $0.60 per share.Snacks giant Mondelez (MDLZ), in an SEC filing, said that it owns 24.24% in Keurig Green Mountain, but expects to own a 13%-14% stake in Keurig Dr. Pepper. It does not plan on investing new capital into the company.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:How To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple Routine

Jana Partners dumped its stake in Snapchat-parent Snap (SNAP) in the second quarter, according to a regulatory filing disclosed Monday, making it the latest fund to do so as the company struggles to compete with the likes of Facebook (FB).XDan Loeb's Third Point Capital also offloaded its shares in Snap in the second quarter, according to a Friday disclosure.Meanwhile, Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital slashed its holdings in Mondelez International (MDLZ) by 27% to roughly 14.5 million shares. The fund's holdings in Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) remained steady at around 2.9 million shares.The Mexican fast-casual chain has been trying for much of the past two years to repair its image following food-safety concerns.Monday is the deadline for big investors to disclose their quarterly holdings. Look for disclosures from Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), George Soros' Soros Fund Management and others later today.Snap tumbled to a record low of 11.28 in morning trade, but rebounded to trade up 6% at 12.54 near midday in the stock market today. Snap crashed 14% on Friday following across-the-board weak Q2 results.Chipotle fell 0.9%, near four-year lows and well below where Pershing Square acquired its stake. Mondelez rose 0.7%.

Snack and beverage giant PepsiCo (PEP) reported second-quarter earnings on Tuesday that topped analyst forecasts. So did sales growth.X Estimates: Earnings per share of $1.39, a 3% increase, as revenue advanced a percentage point higher to $15.59 billion, according to analysts tracked by Zacks Investment Research.Results: Pepsi earned $1.50 a share, including 6 cents from a one-time Britvic sale. That's an 11% gain. Revenue climbed 2% to $15.71 billion. Organic revenue, which includes currency swings and structural changes, advanced 3.1%. Organic volume rose 2% for snacks and other food but fell 2% for beverages.Outlook: Pepsi sees 2017 adjusted earnings of $5.13 a share. Analysts expect $5.12, according to Zacks.Pepsi sees foreign exchange cutting full-year core profit by 2 percentage points vs. its prior estimate of 3 percentage points. The dollar weakened at the end of Q2. The weakening dollar likely will be a notable factor in multinationals' results and guidance during the current earnings season.Shares fell 0.5% to 113.69 in the stock market today. The stock on Monday pierced through support at its 50-day line in heavy volume.PepsiCo, whose brands include its namesake soft drink as well as Mountain Dew, Tropicana, Doritos and Quaker, has tried to offer more "guilt free" products to an increasingly wellness-focused population with a deepening distaste for soda.More than 45% of the company's net revenue comes from those products, the company said during its first-quarter earnings call in April. Meanwhile, U.S. soda sales more broadly have fallen for 12 straight years, according to Beverage Digest, an industry trade publication.PepsiCo has introduced healthier, non-carbonated drinks, tested natural sweeteners in sodas, tried out new frying methods to cut fat in potato chips, and offered up healthier, grain-based snacks, Zacks notes. Emerging markets abroad, where consumption is still low, and a growing middle class in some nations could also drive growth and help demand, Zacks said.But turmoil and currency swings internationally risk cutting into sales figures. Pepsi has tightened up its pricing, which can help protect revenue and make up for weaker volumes. But that tactic's durability could become a bigger issue over time.Volumes in the company's large Frito-Lay North America division fell 1.5% in the first quarter. That marked the first decline in some five years, Jefferies analyst Kevin Grundy said in a report, according to Bloomberg. Management said in April that the dip was temporary and partly a product of shifts in holidays, and that volume had begun to rebound.But Amazon (AMZN) looms over consumer products too. The Amazon-Whole Foods Market (WFM) deal raises the prospect of more private-label goods vs. branded packaged consumer products from the likes of General Mills (GIS), Mondelez (MDLZ) and Pepsi's Frito-Lay. Packaged goods firms are cutting market spending, Marketwatch reported, citing James Cakmak, an analyst at Monness, Crespi, Hardt to support profits. Cakmak wrote in a Monday note that the cuts are in part reflect less of an emphasis of fighting for shelf space in the age of Amazon and other e-commerce options such as Jet.com and Walmart.com from Wal-Mart (WMT). But cutting ads and marketing may only spur the push to commoditize packaged goods, reducing margins further.Coca-Cola (KO) dipped 0.1%. Coca-Cola fell below its 50-day line last week.Monster Beverage (MNST) slid 0.1%. Monster Beverage recently found 50-day support after a failed late June breakout. Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) rose 0.2%.National Beverage (FIZZ) edged down 0.2%. National Beverage, fueled by its Lacroix sparking water, shot up nearly 7% to 103.28 on Monday, now extended from Friday's breakout from a 96.15 buy point of a flat base.RELATED:Is This Unique Soda Maker Set To Pop Its Top, Or Fizzle?Thirsty Investors Drive Coca-Cola Shares Higher As Buy Point FormsNot Your Father's PepsiCo: Company Expands Into Healthy Fare

Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi met with top executives from Apple (AAPL), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, Amazon (AMZN) and others in the tech, banking and consumer industries  on Sunday, ahead of his meeting with President Trump on Monday.Apple CEO Tim Cook, Google CEO Sundar Pichai, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, and Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayan attended a round table Sunday, along with Mondelez (MDLZ) CEO Irene Rosenfeld, Mastercard (MA) CEO Ajay Bhanga, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon,  David Rubenstein from the Carlyle Group and David Yergin from IHS Markit.The executives reportedly told Modi that India's tough business climate and bureaucracy make it hard to operate there, but Cook and Dimon said afterwards the meeting was  positive and productive.Wal-Mart (WMT) CEO Doug McMilon asked for a private meeting with Modi after the group meeting as the company looks to expand operations in India, according to a CNBC report,The big-box retailer has had trouble navigating India's regulatory system and in 2013 dissolved its joint venture, Bharti Wal-Mart, over corruption charges and other issues.Apple shares were up 0.1% at 146.39 in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Alphabet shares were down 0.9%. Amazon shares dipped 0.6%. JPMorgan was up 0.5%. Wal-Mart rallied 1.1%. Mastercard eased 0.2% and Mondelez gained 0.2%.Defense will likely be a big topic when Trump and Modi meet as India plans to spend $150 billion on its military.The Trump administration has reportedly authorized the sale of 22 General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper drones, valued at $22 billion, to India. The deal would still need approval from Congress.Last week, Lockheed Martin (LMT) agreed to send its Texas-based F-16 production to India, if it secures a major fighter deal from New Delhi.Other possible defense deals between the U.S. and India could include Lockheed's C-130J and Boeing's (BA) P-8 maritime surveillance aircraft.Another topic on the table is the H-1B visa program, which Trump has put under review as part of his "hire American buy American" initiative. Without the visa, Indian IT workers would be shut out from working in Silicon Valley.Modi reportedly will highlight the jobs created by Indian-Americans and could use Infosys (INFY), an Indian IT company that pledged to hire 10,000 Americans, as an example a two-way street of investment in hiring between the U.S. and India.RELATED: Amazon's Reentry Into Smartphones Signals Battle For India E-Commerce

Planet Fitness (PLNT), Mondelez International (MDLZ), Diamondback Energy (FANG) and Devon Energy (DVN) topped estimates late Tuesday, while Inphi (IPHI) sank on weak guidance.Estimates: Profit to vault 63% to 44 cents a share, on a 40.6% sales gain to $93.51 million.Results: EPS of 44 cents on revenue of $93.6 million.Outlook: Q2 EPS of 27-39 cents, well below consensus for 46 cents, on revenue of $80 million-$88 million, below consensus for $96.3 million."However, Q2 revenue will be adversely impacted primarily by inventory accumulation in China Long Haul and Metro, which represents 40% of worldwide optical communications demand," said CEO Ford Tamer in a statement. "We are confident in the growth opportunities for Inphi in 2017 and 2018, in the long haul, metro and inter- and intra-data center markets, because of our product positioning with leading customers and growing market share,"Stock: Inphi sank 15% late. Shares finished 4.3% lower at 40.54 amid a broad semiconductor sell-off. The fabless chip designer, which has an optical communications unit, reports ahead of fiber-optic parts maker Lumentum (LITE), which is set to reveal fiscal Q3 earnings early Thursday.Also after the close, optical equipment maker Oclaro (OCLR) gave weak revenue guidance, sending shares down 7%. Lumentum fell 4% late, and Acacia Communications (ACIA) lost 1.7%.Estimates: EPS should climb 4.2% to 50 cents despite a 1.3% revenue dip to $6.372 billion.Results: EPS of 53 cents on revenue of $6.41 billion.Stock: Mondelez rallied 3% late. Shares fell 0.7% to 43.77. Shares were back below the 50-day, where they have traded for much of the past year. Its 52-week high in February came amid merger buzz.Estimates: Per-share earnings of 16 cents, rising from a year-ago gain of 15 cents. Revenue is seen rising 8.4%, to $90.38 million.Results: EPS of 19 cents on revenue of $91.1 million.Outlook: Full-year EPS of 74-77 cents, vs. consensus views for 75 cents, on revenue of $404 million-$415 million.Stock: Planet Fitness edged up 0.15% late. Shares closed down 1% at 20.27. The gym chain remains lodged well below a 22.23 buy point from a cup-shaped, first-stage base, having made a negligible advance from earlier breakouts in the past year.Analysts have been bullish on Planet Fitness' unique strategy that marries low membership costs with a judgment-free setting.RELATED:Planet Fitness Bumps 'Gymtimidation' Lunks To Powerlift Its GymsEstimates: Earnings to rocket to 60 cents from 2 cents a year ago, as sales climb 150.2% to $218.9 million.Results: EPS of $1.04 on revenue of $235 million. Production rose 61%, including an acquisition.Outlook: Diamondback Energy kept its full-year spending outlook of $800 million-$1 billion.Stock: Diamondback dipped 0.4% late. The shale producer ended down 0.6% at 98.38 as oil prices sold off. Shares have been consolidating for nearly three months and were testing long-term support levels on Tuesday.Estimates: Per-share profit of 40 cents vs. a year-ago loss of 53 cents, as revenue soars 43.2%, to $3.045 billion.Results: EPS of 41 cents on revenue of $3.55 billion.Outlook: Devon maintained its full-year capex spending outlook of $2.285 billion-$2.69 billion.Stock: Deven rallied 2.3%. Shares dropped 1.2% at 38.85.RELATED: Apple Beats Views On Earnings, Comes Up Short On Sales Gilead Stock Topples On Consensus-Lagging Q1 Sales, EarningsPaycom Software Earnings, Revenue Top Estimates Twilio Earnings Beat, Guidance Falls Short, Stock Plummets

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 futures early Tuesday morning edged higher, indicating a slightly higher open. Apple (AAPL), Pfizer (PFE) and MasterCard (MA) headline 10 S&P 100 components with earnings on tap Tuesday, as several hundred companies are due to report.All eyes will be on Apple, which reports after the closing bell. Apple has the world's largest market cap at $769 billion, with shares trading at all-time highs. Investors are looking past current sluggish growth to the iPhone 8 — and possible dividend hikes and new buybacks. And Apple's results and guidance are likely to have a big impact on a slew of suppliers, especially chipmakers.Several other megacaps are on tap, including drug giants Pfizer and Merck before the open. Like Apple, Pfizer and Merck are part of the Dow industrials, which continue to lag, falling slightly Monday as the Nasdaq composite powered to a new all-time high — thanks to Apple, Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN) and other big-cap techs.Altria (MO), CVS Health (CVS), ConocoPhillips (COP), Emerson Electric (EMR), Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Mondelez (MDLZ) round out the S&P 100 companies on tap.Late Monday, Dow and Nasdaq 100 futures rose 0.1% above fair value. So did S&P 500 index futures. In Asian trading, Japan's Nikkei rose 0.7%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed 0.3% and the Shanghai composite fell 0.2%.IBD'S TAKE: Apple is on Leaderboard, IBD's premium service offering annotated charts of a select group of stocks, mostly growth companies that are in or near buy zones. Take a free Leaderboard trial today.Meanwhile, General Motors (GM), Ford (F) and other automakers will release U.S. auto sales for April, with analysts expecting modest but broad-based declines as U.S. demand continues to decline vs. a year earlier. General Motors and Ford, both S&P 100 members, reported earnings last week.The Federal Reserve begins its two-day policy meeting. Analysts don't see any real chance of a move Wednesday, but policymakers could reinforce expectations of a June move while bringing forward estimates for another hike or paring back the central bank's massive balance sheet.RELATED:These Are The Buy Points For Apple Before Earnings: Stock Still In Buy Range?Apple Stock Hits Record High With Q2 Earnings On TapApril U.S. Auto Sales: What To Expect From GM, Ford As Tesla Soars Into EarningsThese Are The Five 'Top 5%' Stocks With Earnings Due This Week

JAB, which owns Caribou Coffee, Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, Keurig Green Mountain and Peet's Coffee & Tea, agreed to buy Panera Bread (PNRA) Wednesday for $7.5 billion, including debt, as competition in the coffee space heats up.X Luxembourg-based JAB will pay $315 per share for the fast-casual bakery, shares of which had shot higher in recent weeks amid takeover talk. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter.Panera shares jumped 14.2% to close at 312.94 on the stock market today.JAB also has a joint venture with D.E. Master Blenders 1753 and Mondelez International (MDLZ).But JAB may be looking to reduce its exposure to the coffee business as competition intensifies.Java leader Starbucks (SBUX), for example, has seen its share of foot traffic fall to 11% in February from 12% in January, according marketing firm xAd.Meanwhile, Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) has stepped up its offerings, and McDonald's (MCD) is selling $2 McCafe drinks and $1 sodas all this month.But outside coffee, JAB has stakes in beauty brand Coty and luxury shoemaker Jimmy Choo. And earlier this week, JAB announced a deal to license Burberry Group beauty brands.McDonald's shares closed up 0.9% at 130.41 Wednesday, breaking out from its 130.10 buy point in a cup with handle base. Dunkin' fell 3%, and Starbucks dipped 0.2% to 58.22, but still near its own buy point of 59.64.RELATED: Dave & Buster's Guides Light After Q4 Beats; Ollie's Tops, Guides HighHappy Meals On Wheels: McDonald's Touts '3-Mile' Delivery Advantage

Stocks were mixed at the start of trading Tuesday as tech stock downgrades weighed, but Caterpillar (CAT) rose on an analyst upgrade.The Nasdaq was up 0.1% as the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 dipped 0.1%.Dow component Caterpillar rose 1%. Goldman Sachs added the maker of earth-moving equipment to its conviction buy list and assigned it a price target of 120. Cat has been posting tight weekly closes, a sign of institutional support as it works to shape a bottom to its seven-week consolidation.Visa (V), JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) were lower in the Dow. Each fell less than 1%.Among the last few stragglers in the fourth-quarter reporting season, Conn's (CONN) soared 31% after delivering mixed results. Earnings topped targets by a wide margin, but revenue missed. Management projected the company would return to full-year profitability in fiscal 2018.Small biotechs were once again punching out some significant early moves. Paratek Pharmaceuticals (PRTK) rocketed 28% after it reported that a Phase 3 clinical trial of its pneumonia treatment Omadacycline met primary and secondary targets. Cyclacel Pharma (CYCC) shot up 18%. The New Jersey-based drugmaker reported an independent study demonstrating therapeutic potential in the company's CYC065 as an anti-cancer agent.Alphabet (GOOGL) fell less than 1% after BMO Capital trimmed the stock to market perform from outperform and lowered its price target to 880 from 1,005. The downgrade followed news reports late Monday on more details emerging in Google's accusation that former executive Anthony Levandowski and others stole technology to develop the driverless auto technologies.Alphabet shares are fighting to hold support at their 10-week moving average, after falling below an 867.10 buy point in a flat base.IBD'S TAKE: Marketsmith, IBD's chart and screening service has open access this week. Check out Marketsmith's annotated charts and daily lists of stocks breaking out past proper buy points and those that are near entries.Among IBD 50 stocks, Nvidia (NVDA) dropped nearly 5% at the open. The chipmaker received a downgrade to underweight from sector weight from Pacific Crest Securities based on the company's broad penetration of its available markets. Pacific Crest has no price target on the stock.IBD 50 stock Mondelez International (MDLZ) jumped 0.9% after Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock to buy, from neutral. Shares are trading below their 10-week moving average in a flat consolidation.Kate Spade (KATE) tanked 14% at the open on reports that the company may take additional time to contemplate a takeover offer from Coach (COH).  Kate Spade shares jumped nearly 30% in February, boosted by word that both Coach and Michael Kors (KORS) were contemplating bids.The U.S. trade gap narrowed to $43.6 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported. That was down from $48.5 billion in January — a bigger move than the dip to $44.5 billion projected by economists.  The deficit has been up and down since December, following a three-month advance.The Commerce Department reports February factory order estimates at 10 a.m. ET.Oil prices rose, sending West Texas Intermediate up 0.5% and holding still below $51 a barrel. Gold gained a half percent and hovered near $1,261 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. The 10-year yield added 1 basis point to 2.33%.In international markets, stocks gained in China on Tuesday with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index adding another 0.6%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 0.9%.Europe's markets were mixed in afternoon trade. London's FTSE 100 climbed 0.4%, while benchmarks in Paris and Frankfurt held thin losses.RELATED:Google Working Hard To End Ad Flap That Derailed Stock Market RallyThree Top China Stocks To Watch Ahead Of Trump-Xi: Investing Action Plan

The major indexes continued to gain altitude Thursday afternoon on expectations that the U.K.'s central bank will cut interest rates, while a breakout from defense giant Lockheed Martin (LMT) provided a bullish move among the big caps.Bank of England Gov. Mark Carney signaled that the central bank would ease policy this summer in the wake of the U.K.'s vote to leave the European Union. Carney cited uncertainty over Brexit and said policymakers would likely take steps to try to offset the negative impact.The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 1.1%, while the Nasdaq advanced 1%. The S&P and Dow rose back above their 50-day moving averages, an encouraging step as indexes recover from the Brexit sell-off. The Nasdaq rose back above its 200-day, and is close to retaking its 50-day as well.Volume was tracking lower across the board. But breadth was strong, with winners topping losers by 11-to-5 on the NYSE and by 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Lockheed Martin broke out of a flat base, rising nearly 2%, above the 245.47 buy point in active trading. The seven-week pattern exhibited tight trading and evidence of institutional buying, which should bode well for Thursday's breakout.The maker of the F-35 stealth fighter and other major weapons has a mediocre EPS Rating from IBD, but analysts expect a 16% EPS increase in 2017. Japan plans to acquire new fighter jets, and Reuters on Thursday quoted people familiar with the project as saying Boeing (BA) and Lockheed Martin have been invited to submit proposals.Which defense contractor has the best ratings in its group? Find out with IBD Stock Checkup.Food stocks were leading the stock market today, but it wasn't necessarily a move to defensive stocks. There was more news of consolidation, something that has shone a positive light on food sector.Hershey (HSY) was halted up 15.2% to a record high in tremendous volume after the Wall Street Journal reported that Mondelez (MDLZ) approached the company with a buyout proposal. The deal would unite the world's No. 2 and No. 5 (Hershey) confectionery companies, according to research firm Euromonitor. Mondelez shares rose 4% in active volume.Darden Restaurants (DRI) sank 3% in heavy volume after the parent company of Olive Garden, Yard House and other chains missed sales expectations. Earnings for the May-ended quarter were $1.10 a share, up 9% on an adjusted basis. Sales from continuing operations increased 2.1%.Darden forecast earnings for the fiscal year that started this month of $3.80 to $3.90 a share, below the consensus estimate of $3.99. Shares fell below the 200-day moving average.Tractor Supply (TSCO) slid 3% in huge volume after the farming supply retailer missed earnings estimates and reduced its outlook late Wednesday. The stock slid below its 50-day moving average but continued to work on a flat base.

Stocks rallied for a third straight session Thursday as the Bank of England hinted at fresh stimulus measures. Meanwhile, Hershey (HSY), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and NetEase (NTES) made big moves.The S&P 500 led with a 1.4% gain, while the Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average added 1.3% each. Preliminary figures showed volume was slightly higher across the board vs. Wednesday. The Nasdaq retook both its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, one day after the Dow and S&P 500 reclaimed their 50-day lines.Food stocks were big winners in the stock market today. Hershey soared 17% to a new high in massive volume amid reports on a buyout offer from Mondelez International (MDLZ), which rose 6%. Later in the day, the chocolate maker's board of directors unanimously rejected the 107-per-share cash-and-stock bid.IBD 50 stock Constellation Brands (STZ) gapped up and rose 4% in busy turnover. It briefly cleared a 165.91 flat-base entry. The maker of Corona beer, Robert Mondavi wine and other alcoholic beverages reported fiscal Q1 earnings and sales that topped views.Also on the IBD 50, NetEase continued its winning ways, following through on Wednesday's breakout with a 6% jump in high turnover. Shares are now extended past a 179.20 cup-with-handle buy point.Defense contractor Lockheed Martin soared 2%, clearing the 245.47 buy point of a flat base in fast trade. It's still in buy range from the entry. The F-35 fighter jet maker and rival Boeing (BA) are among those invited to submit a proposal as Japan plans to acquire new fighter jets, according to Reuters.Boeing lifted more than 2% to finish among the Dow's top gainers. The airplane maker is thinking about adding extra seats to its biggest 777 wide-body jet to compete with Airbus' (EADSY) A380 super jumbo jet, according to Bloomberg.Gaming software and steel stocks also outperformed. Laggards included ship transporters, energy and medical stocks. Oil stocks dipped as West Texas intermediate crude sank 3% to $48.38 a barrel.How is your stock performing in its industry group? Find out now with IBD Stock Checkup.In economic news, first-time jobless claims rose 3% to 268,000 the week ended June 25, slightly above forecasts for 266,000 claims. The Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index for June rose back above the neutral 50 level to 56.8, from 49.3 in May.Economic data on tap Friday include the ISM manufacturing index for June, motor vehicle sales, also for June, and May construction spending.

Emmanuel Faber's first big move as Danone's chief, the $10 billion takeover of WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), is a foray into soy milk, protein shakes and kale aimed at kickstarting growth at the French yogurt maker grappling with a drop in dairy consumption.The Paris-based producer of Actimel drinks and Evian bottled water agreed to buy the U.S. company for $56.25 a share in cash, acquiring leadership in the burgeoning natural and organic food sector through its biggest acquisition in almost a decade.After spending his first year trying to revive sluggish sales in Danone's core European dairy segment, Faber is now expanding his portfolio to include a broad range of faster-growing, higher-margin items like the Silk brand soy beverage, cashew milk and soy yogurts that cater to more affluent and health-conscious consumers. The agreement is a victory for Douglas L. Braunstein and James C. Woolery, former JPMorgan Chase (JPM) bankers, who prodded WhiteWave to consider a sale through their investment fund."The purchase will allow us to double the size of our U.S. business and become the world leader in organic," Faber, who joined Danone in 1997 and became CEO in October 2014, said on a conference call with journalists.WhiteWave soared 19.8% to $56.80 in trading before U.S. exchanges opened on the stock market today. Danone jumped 3.9% to 65.76 euros at 1 p.m. in Paris.IBD'S TAKE: WhiteWave shares were breaking out of an 11-month base before the Danone takeover bid. But it's only rated No. 4 in its industry group. Find out who the leaders are in the IBD Stock Checkup.The acquisition would make Danone the global leader in fresh dairy and health-food brands including Horizon milk, Wallaby Organic yogurt and Earthbound Farm packaged salads as consumers increasingly shun processed foods perceived as unhealthy. The deal is the second potential takeover in the food industry in recent weeks, following the Mondelez International (MDLZ) advance towards Hershey (HSY), which the chocolate maker snubbed. Both of those deals aim to beef up the acquirer's presence in the U.S.In recent years, dairy milk's reputation as nature's perfect food has suffered as consumers question its nutritional merits as well as the environmental costs and treatment of animals housed at big industrial farms. The U.S. organic-food market expanded 11% in 2015 to $43 billion, while the overall food industry grew 3.3%, according to the Organic Trade Association.Unit sales in Danone's fresh-dairy business have fallen for two years straight, weighed down by a slump in Brazil and declining demand in Russia and Europe."The key question to our mind is the real strength of the WhiteWave brands," wrote Jeff Stent, an analyst at Exane BNP Paribas. "To what extent has WhiteWave's success been less about the brands and more about first-mover advantage in a high-growth category. Time will tell."Denver-based WhiteWave began trading in 2012 after U.S. dairy company Dean Foods (DF) spun off the unit, which was its most profitable business. Investors have speculated since then that the company would become an acquisition target.Sales at  WhiteWave will increase about 11% this year, based on the average of analyst estimates, after doubling since 2010 on rising demand for more healthful beverages and food, data compiled by Bloomberg show. North America accounted for 86% of the company's $3.9 billion in revenue last year, with Europe contributing the rest.Growth like that doesn't come cheap -- Danone is paying about 26.2 times earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization for WhiteWave, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. That's well above the median multiple of 14.8 times earnings paid by buyers in acquisitions of dairy companies over the past five years, the data show.The WhiteWave purchase, to be funded through debt, will boost results in the first year after closing, the maker of Activia yogurt said. Danone expects a $300 million boost to operating profit by 2020.Danone, which makes Oikos Greek-style yogurt, is targeting sales growth of more than 5% by 2020, with half of its business keying in on consumers seeking healthy-eating alternatives. North American sales will be 22% of Danone's total revenue after the purchase, compared with 12% now.The purchase values WhiteWave at $12.5 billion including net debt and other liabilities. The companies expect to complete the deal this year. Lazard Ltd. advised Danone, while Goldman Sachs Group Inc. advised WhiteWave.Braunstein and Woolery announced in February that their firm, Hudson Executive Capital LP, had bought shares in six companies, including WhiteWave, with an eye to nudging them to take steps that would boost their stock prices. The investors said they wouldn't pursue proxy fights or publicly berate companies, preferring "constructive engagement."

In the background of another epic bounce for U.S. stocks was the bull market's oldest friend: buybacks.American companies announced $52 billion of repurchases last week alone, following the Federal Reserve's approval of capital plans for 33 financial firms, according to data compiled by Birinyi Associates. That pushed total buybacks in June to more than $65 billion, the most since February.The cascade of announcements came as the S&P 500 Index was erasing a loss that swelled to more than 5% after the U.K. voted to exit the European Union.The Fed's vote of confidence in the ability of U.S. banks to withstand a severe economic shock cleared the way for large firms from Morgan Stanley (MS) to Bank of America (BAC) to outline planned share repurchases last week. Buybacks have been a primary source of buoyancy for the second-longest bull market in history -- a pillar of strength that the Fed has been happy to fuel with dovish monetary policy."It was helpful to the market in the wake of Brexit that all those announcements came last week," said John Carey, a Boston-based fund manager at Pioneer Investment Management, which oversees about $230 billion. "The central bank has signaled that they'll do what they can to support markets by continuing to supply cheap credit and bond-purchasing activity."Resurgent buybacks may help ease or even erase a falloff earlier in the year. Through the first four months of 2016, announced repurchases were down 38% from a year ago.The S&P 500 slipped 3.6% on June 24, the first day of trading after the U.K. voted to leave the EU. That Friday loss marked its biggest daily decline since August. The benchmark index fell another 1.8% the following Monday before reversing course and rising in four straight sessions to end the week. The gauge's 5.1% increase over the period got it back within 0.5% of where it was before the Brexit referendum.Financial shares had the most at stake in the Fed's stress tests, and when the central bank gave the all-clear last Wednesday, they surged on the news. An index of financial stocks in the S&P 500 climbed 3.9% across the following two days.IBD's Take: Shares of JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are all trading below their 50-day and 200-day moving averages.  All have reported declining earnings in some recent quarters as sluggish economic growth and flat yield curves weigh on results.JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) announced $10.6 billion in buybacks, the most out of any financial firm last week, according to Birinyi Associates data. Citigroup (C) authorized $8.6 billion in repurchases, while Bank of America and Morgan Stanley said they'll buy back more than $3.5 billion each.The U.S. stock recovery last week also received a boost from investors closing bearish options bets they'd made heading into the Brexit decision. Short sales had reached the highest since the financial crisis amid the uncertainty leading up to the referendum. The S&P 500 also got a lift from deal activity, as Mondelez International (MDLZ) bid $23 billion for Hershey (HSY) on Thursday.Still, U.S. stocks are going to need alternative sources of strength going forward, like improved growth for both profits and the overall economy, according to Carey. The S&P 500 is expected to see earnings contraction of 5.4% for the second quarter, according to a survey conducted by Bloomberg."We're seeing some steps that could prop up the U.S. market in the near-term," said Carey. "At some point we're going to need economic growth and improving earnings to keep the market going higher."

Stock showed modest losses in early trade Thursday despite some better-than-expected jobs and manufacturing numbers.The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, the S&P 500 gave up 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%The stock market today opens with the S&P 500 back above its 200-day moving average for the first time since early January. The Nasdaq remains about midway between its 50- and 200-day lines, but both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq are tinkering with their fifth straight weekly gains.Initial jobless claims edged up to 265,000 in the week ended March 12 vs. the 258,000 claims the Labor Department reported in the prior week. That was better than the rise to 270,000 claims expected by economist consensus.Mid-Atlantic region manufacturing firmed more than expected in March, lifting the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Business Outlook Survey to 12.4. That reversed a negative 2.8 reading for February, and clobbered consensus expectations of minus 1.4.At 10 a.m. ET, the Labor Department reports its January Jobs Openings and Labor Turnover Survey, and the Conference Board doles out its Leading Economic Index for February.WTI crude oil futures strengthened above $39 a barrel, following up Wednesday's 6% rebound from losses early in the week. Oil is up a bit more than 1% for the week.Dow stocks were mixed, with decliners slightly ahead of advancing stocks. All the moves held to less than 1%.Nasdaq 100 stocks also held to moves of less than 1%. The exception was Mondelez International (MDLZ), which dropped more than 2% after news reports said hedge fund Pershing Square sold 20 million shares of the Illinois-based snack maker. The move reduced Pershing's stake in the company to 5.6%.Laser maker Rofin-Sinar Technologies (RSTI) flashed 35% higher. Peer Coherent (COHR) agreed to buy the Plymouth, Mich.-based company in a $942 million deal. The companies expect the deal to close in six to nine months and anticipate $30 million in cost savings within 18 to 24 months of the close.FedEx (FDX) rumbled up 8% to head the S&P 500 after reporting a solid fiscal third-quarter beat late Wednesday. The stock technically ended Wednesday 1% below a 146.38 buy point in a valid cup-with-handle base. The base formed within a nine-month consolidation.Caterpillar (CAT) fell hard in premarket trading but recovered by the open. A regulatory filing forecast first-quarter revenue of $9.4 billion or less, below consensus views for $10.3 billion. It forecast adjusted EPS of 70 cents or lower vs. views for 97 cents. The heavy equipment maker maintained its full-year guidance. Shares eased 0.3%.Inside the IBD 50,  Maxlinear (MXL) gave up 1% in early trading. A 6% spike in powerful trade on Wednesday put the Carlsbad, Calif.-based chipmaker 12% past a 16.29 buy point. But 17.85 is also a legitimate buy point.Overseas markets played catch-up to Wednesday's Fed announcement, made after most markets were closed. Benchmark indexes in Shanghai and Hong Kong rose more than 1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan dipped 0.2%. Eurozone exchanges in Frankfurt and Paris were under pressure, with the CAC 40 in Paris and the DAX in Frankfurt off nearly 2% each near midday. Outside the eurozone, London's FTSE 100 traded down 0.3%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Food shares are rallying as news of the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with ketchup giant H.J. Heinz is making investors' mouths water.Kraft is surging 41% near noon in the stock market today on the news that Heinz owners 3G Capital and Berkshire Hathaway will buy the cheese and snack maker.Shares of Oreo maker Mondelez International (MDLZ) — a Kraft spinoff — are up 2.6%. Cereal giant General Mills (GIS) shares ticked up 2.4%. Dean Foods (DF) rose 1.9%. J.M. Smucker (SJM) shares 2.3%. ConAgra Foods (CAG) shares edged up 1.4%. Kellogg (K) also climbed 1.4%.Natural food makers Hain Celestial (HAIN) shares rose 2.9% and WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) shares bumped up 1.7%, both hitting new highs.Campbell Soup (CPB) shares essentially remained flat, edging up 0.3%.Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) A-class and Berkshire (BRKB) B-class shares edged lower.Looking further down the road, Mondelez, Pinnacle Foods (PF) and B&G Foods (BG) could potentially benefit from the merger, according to RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer.If Kraft moves to sell non-core businesses like frozen foods, Birds Eye parent Pinnacle could be a potential buyer, while B&G might eye Kraft's other non-core brands, said Palmer in a note.And Palmer speculates that Mondelez could be the next big acquisition target.According to a recent PwC report, merger deals may be key in streamlining increasingly large portfolios."M&A is likely to become increasingly important, not just in growing food companies, but in streamlining and focusing them," it said.Other recent food mergers include Tyson Foods' (TSN) acquisition of Hillshire Brands and General Mills' buyout of Annie's.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:3G Capital, Berkshire To Buy Kraft, Merge With Heinz.
The ink hasn't dried on the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with H.J. Heinz, but analysts already are speculating which brands may be sold and which food companies are next on the M&A menu.

3G Capital and Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway  (BRKA), which acquired Heinz in 2013, said Wednesday they will buy Kraft to forge Kraft Heinz Co. Kraft holders will get shares in the merged company, plus a special $16.50 a share dividend, paid for by $10 billion from 3G and Berkshire.
Kraft stock rose 35.6% to 83.17.

Kraft Heinz would be the world's No. 5 food and beverage company, with eight brands topping $1 billion in annual sales. It would team Kraft's Velveeta, Lunchables and Oscar Mayer with Heinz's flagship ketchup and baked beans.

The combined company may look to sell a few noncore or regional businesses, said RBC Capital Markets David Palmer in a note released before Wednesday's official confirmation. B&G Foods (BG) might be a buyer. And Heinz's frozen portfolio, which includes Weight Watchers Smart Ones and Ore Ida, might appeal to Pinnacle Foods (PF).
Last year, Hillshire Brands axed its quest for Pinnacle after agreeing to be acquired itself by meat producer Tyson Foods (TSN).
3G's past gives some hints about which businesses might be cut.

"A fair amount of brand pruning could be in the cards, similar to the actions 3G has taken since owning Heinz (such as shedding Shanghai Long Fong Foods in China and the U.S. foodservice dessert business in 2013)," said Morningstar analyst Erin Lash in a note.
Jell-O's standing, in particular, might look wobbly.

"We've thought for some time that Jell-O, which continues to falter despite multiple stabs at putting it on more stable ground, could be axed in favor of allocating more capital to faster-growing categories such as organics," Lash wrote, adding, "this could occur in a more rapid fashion under its new ownership."

As consumer tastes have veered toward more healthful fare, so too have packaged food giants. General Mills (GIS) bought natural-foods maker Annie's last year. Before that, Campbell Soup (CPB) bought baby food maker Plum Organics and salad dressing brand Bolthouse Farms.
WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), maker of Silk soy and almond milk, rose 1.3%. Hain Celestial (HAIN) hit 66.35 early, but closed up 0.6% at 63.83.
Among larger food stocks, Mondelez International (MDLZ) — which split from Kraft in 2012 — rose 2.3%. General Mills edged up 1% and Kellogg (K) 0.3%.

"While the possible purchase of Kraft makes another deal likely impossible for several years, ultimately we believe Mondelez to be the clear 'next deal,'" noted Palmer. It would "reunite Kraft's global grocery brands (e.g. Philadelphia) and give Heinz's international business needed scale."
But combining brands might not always be the best strategy, as a recent PwC report cautions.

"It's no longer an asset-based game. Large, diversified food companies are struggling to compete with smaller, more focused enterprises," noted authors J. Neely and John Potter. "These companies need to be thinking beyond scale about what it is they do better than anyone else."The ink hasn't dried on the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with H.J. Wall Street was sweet on PepsiCo (PEP) Wednesday after the snack and soda company topped fourth-quarter expectations and announced a share buyback program for up to $12 billion of common stock.Its annualized dividend also will grow 7.3% to $2.81 a share, and the company expects 7% earnings growth for the year — above analyst estimates for 2.6% growth to $4.75 a share."As we look ahead to 2015, we expect to again deliver results consistent with our long-term financial objectives, despite the anticipated challenging and volatile global macro environment," CEO Indra Nooyi said in the company's earnings release. "Further, returning cash to shareholders remains a top priority, and we plan to return approximately $8.5 to $9 billion to shareholders through both higher dividends and share repurchases."Shares were up 1.9% on the stock market today, climbing further above their 50-day line after retaking it Tuesday.In Q4, earnings excluding items grew 6.7% to $1.12 a share, above views by 4 cents. Including restructuring and impairment charges, the remeasurement of monetary assets at Venezuelan entities, a pension lump sum settlement charge, and mark-to-market net losses on commodity hedges, PepsiCo earned $1.3 billion, or 87 cents a share.Revenue was negatively impacted by foreign exchange translation, including "significant currency volatility" in Russia and Venezuela, and dipped 0.8% to $19.95 billion. But that still beat consensus estimates for $19.66 billion.Cheetos and SunChips maker Frito-Lay North America grew net revenue by 3%, while Quaker Foods North America revenue fell 2%.Asia, Middle East and Africa segment revenue rose 4%, but the stronger dollar bogged down the Latin America Foods segment, with net revenue dipping 0.5% despite an 11% rise in organic revenue driven by growth in Venezuela, Argentina and Brazil. Net revenue in Europe fell 10% in spite of a 6% rise in organic revenue, also hit by foreign exchange translations.PepsiCo Americas Beverages revenue edged up 1% as the soda maker said it claimed more market share.Mondelez International (MDLZ) also reported Wednesday, beating Q4 earnings views by 4 cents with an 11.9% bump to 47 cents a share. But the Oreos and Ritz crackers maker missed sales estimates slightly with a 6.9% year-over-year decline to $8.83 billion. The company said it expects adjusted per-share earnings to "increase at a double-digit rate."Beverage giant Coca-Cola (KO) beat Q4 views Tuesday with earnings of 44 cents a share on revenue of $10.9 billion. Coke, too, said it expects to be dogged by a volatile macro environment.Dr. Pepper Snapple (DPS) reports on Thursday.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

The maker of Oreos and Cadburys, Mondelez International (MDLZ), will soon be making mooncakes as well, following its just-announced 80% stake in Vietnam's largest confectionery business, Kinh Do. The $370 million deal, which will give Mondelez access to the Southeast Asian snack maker's manufacturing and distribution facilities, is expected to close in the second quarter of 2015, pending Kinh Do…
Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) is sending most of its U.S. coffee-buying operations from Vermont to Lausanne, Switzerland, this spring, according to Reuters.

The maker of Keurig brewers and single-serve K-Cup coffee pods isn't the first U.S. coffee giant to go overseas to the commodity market hub. Kraft (KRFT) spin-off Mondelez International (MDLZ) also has buying operations in Switzerland, and Starbucks (SBUX) has been there for over 10 years. More than 60% of the world's coffee beans are traded in commodity markets in the country.
This fall, Keurig started Keurig Trading GmbH, a new corporate entity in Switzerland.
The country has favorable tax laws and light regulation, making it home to big commodity merchants, like Glencore and Trafigura. In 2012, commodity traders made the country over $13 billion.
Keurig wouldn't say if its move is due to the more favorable tax environment, but its Canadian procurement operations won't be affected.

Keurig has been gaining popularity as consumers crave individualized drinks with a wide variety of flavor options. Coca-Cola (KO) is bullish on the company and bought a stake to develop a cold beverage system
Keurig fell below its 50-day line on Nov. 21, a day after reporting the first single-digit percentage EPS growth since 2012, and has since struggled to retake that level of support.

President Trump has visions of a massive Apple (AAPL) factory opening in the U.S. to churn out the latest iPhone. The idea is not completely far-fetched, but one thing seems clear: If it happens, most of the new jobs will go to robots.Even in lower-cost China, Foxconn, which assembles the iPhone there, reportedly replaced 60,000 workers with robots at one facility. That's more than half the facility's workforce. Foxconn says it is adding 10,000 "Foxbots" per year.China has seen its cost advantage wither away due to wage gains. It's investing more than $3 billion a year in robots — up from next to nothing before 2009 — to keep from losing its manufacturing base to lower-cost developing nations, Bernstein analysts Michael Parker and Alberto Moel wrote in a December report.Trump has vowed to rewrite or walk away from trade deals and cut corporate tax rates to level the playing field for U.S. companies. He told Congress on Feb. 28 that he'll "bring back millions of jobs."Although economists concur that North American Free Trade Agreement and China's admission to the World Trade Organization have taken a toll on U.S. manufacturing jobs, Trump's battle plan seems geared to fight the last war.If China must shrink its costs with a massive deployment of robots, U.S.-based manufacturers that pay much higher wages and benefits will face the same pressures.A 2015 study by Boston Consulting Group found that an automotive industry welder earned about $25 an hour, including benefits, while a robot could do the job for $8 an hour, including installation, maintenance and operating costs. The gap is expected to widen sharply as technology improves."It is still possible to force the relocation of production" by restricting trade via tariffs or applying political pressure, wrote Bernstein's Parker and Moel. "However, if the point of the exercise is to restore well-paying, middle-class jobs in manufacturing in the process, the result is going to disappoint. Mandating a physical task be carried out in a high-cost labor market in 2017 is simply going to increase the chances the task is automated."Trump relentlessly bashed air conditioning company Carrier during the campaign for its plan to close an Indiana factory and move the work to Mexico. He intervened in December, saving about 800 jobs — for now. But Carrier's parent, United Technologies (UTX), which is getting $7 million in tax incentives from Indiana to stay, said it would invest $16 million to automate the factory "to drive the cost down."Like Apple, United Technologies is a member of Dow Jones industrial average.United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes told CNBC that while moving to Mexico would have been cheaper, the company will "make that plant competitive just because we'll make the capital investments there, but what that ultimately means is there will be fewer jobs."Mondelez (MDLZ), the maker of Oreos, was another regular Trump campaign target for its decision to cut 600 jobs from a Chicago factory and move the work to Mexico. The company said it considered installing new production lines at its Chicago Nabisco plant but chose to do the work in Salinas, Mexico, because of a $46 million cost differential. Mondelez noted that even if the project had gone forward in Chicago, half the jobs would have been eliminated because of new labor-saving technology.IBD'S TAKE: Since taking office, President Trump has talked less about the sticks he'll use against U.S. trading partners and more about the carrots he'll offer to manufacture in the U.S. via tax reform. But, for now, Trump's economic agenda and his tax cuts for business are stuck in line behind the ObamaCare repeal effort.The food and beverage industry is expected to be among the bigger adopters of industrial robots in coming years, says Boston Consulting Group, with automakers and electronics firms continuing to lead the way. Metals and machinery, rubber and plastics, and pharmaceuticals and cosmetics are also seen ramping up robot use. A 2016 McKinsey & Co. study concluded that 59% of manufacturing activities could be automated.Foxconn said in January that it's mulling a $7 billion highly automated factory for making displays, including flat-panel TVs and monitors, in the U.S. in partnership with Apple. Transportation costs for ever-larger displays, which aren't shipped by plane like the iPhone, are a driving force behind the plan. Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou said March 1 that such plans are on hold as the company waits to see what bills are passed and what incentives are offered.Pegatron, another Apple contract manufacturer that does assembly for Dell and HP Inc. (HPQ) out of plants in California and Indiana, reportedly said after Trump's election that it could expand its U.S. capacity fourfold, relying on automation and with a minimal increase in labor. The tech industry began formulating its response last year in the event that Trump was elected and turned out to be serious about imposing 35% tariffs on imports from China.Trump hasn't threatened such hefty tariffs in recent weeks. The focus has shifted to House Republicans' plan to slash the corporate tax rate to 20% and make export revenues tax-free. The 20% rate would apply to the full value of imports, raising $1 trillion over a decade that would effectively pay for the corporate tax cut. Still, economists who back the idea say that the dollar would rise 25%, offsetting any trade advantage. Major importers like Wal-Mart (WMT) hate the idea and trade experts warn that the WTO would likely find the import tax to be illegal.Some companies haven't needed new tax deals or threats to open factories in the U.S., but automation is key to their strategies.Adidas is a prime example. The maker of athletic shoes, which has long done its labor-intensive manufacturing out of China, Indonesia and Vietnam, last year piloted what it's calling a Speedfactory in Germany, making shoes almost entirely by robots. This year, the second Adidas Speedfactory is slated to open in Atlanta, where it's expected to employ 160 people facilitating the production of a half-million shoes.The high-tech operation, Adidas says, won't just eliminate the drudgery in manufacturing (along with a lot of the workers). It also will enable the company "to make product for the consumer, with the consumer, where the consumer lives in real time, unleashing unparalleled creativity and endless opportunities for customization."Meanwhile, Nike (NKE), another Dow industrials component, and Under Armour (UAA) are both developing strategies for manufacturing in the U.S., close to their customers. It's a safe bet that robots will be doing most of the work.The implications for workers are clear, says Boston Consulting Group. "As U.S. factories adopt advanced manufacturing technologies, demand will surge for higher-skilled, white-collar workers who can quickly adapt to new technologies and processes, and demand will lessen for blue-collar workers who are trained in specific skills."Despite his vow to bring back millions of jobs, Trump isn't oblivious to the job threat posed by robots. In a postelection interview, the New York Times asked Trump whether he was worried that companies will keep their factories in the U.S. but automate their workers out of jobs."They will, and we'll make the robots too," Trump said. He added: "Right now we don't make the robots. We don't make anything. But we're going to. I mean, look, robotics is becoming very big and we're going to do that."Trump is more right than wrong about the U.S. ceding an opportunity, writes Frank Tobe, publisher of the Robot Report. "Two-thirds of the robotics industry and 100% of industrial robots are manufactured outside of the U.S. by non-U.S. companies."China's leadership has fully embraced the adoption of robots as part of its "Made in China 2025" strategy. The plan reflects not only wage pressures but demographics, as its working-age population shrinks. Whether the U.S. will avoid committing to robots for fear of displacing workers is a real question with serious competitive implications.Academics and industry leaders made the case in "A Roadmap for U.S. Robotics" last fall that robots have been a plus for manufacturing jobs. "Over the last 5-6 years we have seen introduction of 600,000 new jobs in manufacturing. During the same period, we have seen significant growth in adoption of robot systems in industry," they wrote.Yet their upbeat predictions come with some uncertainty. The auto industry has been the biggest adopter of robotics, but that's happened as sales rebounded from just 10.4 million in 2009 to a record high 17.5 million in 2016. But if demand has peaked, as industry players suspect, then increasing automation may not be quite so positive for employment in auto manufacturing in the future.RELATED:U.S. Manufacturing Gears Up As 'America First' Trump Takes OfficeThe Top 10 Jobs Robots Could Steal From Humans By 2025Forget The Doomsday Clock, There's Now A Robot Fear IndexThe Trump Economy: Jobs, Regulations, Taxes And Trade

When it comes to long-term performance, less than 60 basis points separates the top five performing international stock mutual funds in the IBD Best Mutual Funds 2017 Awards list in IBD's 2017 survey of the best and brightest active fund managers.But one thing is common: All five mauled the scrawny return of the MSCI EAFE (Europe, Australasia and Far East) equity benchmark.Each award winner beat the benchmark in the last year, the past three, five and 10 years. Award winners were ranked by 10-year average annual returns with the top five earning recognition as the best of the best.The $2 billion Thornburg Global Opportunities I(THOIX) ranked 1st among 438 funds having a 10-year track record, showing an annual average return of 7.95%. That's more than 10 times the 0.75% gain for MSCI EAFE over the same time frame.Matthews Asia Dividend Fund(MAPIX) was 2nd with a 7.60% return, followed by Morgan Stanley Institutional Global Franchise (IMSFAX) at 7.46%, Oppenheimer Global Opportunities Class A(OPGIX) 7.40% and Oakmark Global Select(OAKWX) 7.39%.Four of the top five performers searched the entire globe for good stocks. Just one, Matthews Asia Dividend Investor, focuses on the Asia and Pacific region; in fact, the $5 billion fund must invest at least 80% of total assets in dividend-paying equity securities of companies located in Asia.Why has Thornburg done well?Contrary to its name, the fund actually takes a larger stake in U.S. companies than you might think. Historically, American companies have made up 30% to 50% of the entire portfolio. Emerging markets have taken up just 5% to 20%.As of Jan. 31, indeed, the U.S. comprised 45.1% of the entire fund. Netherlands was 2nd at 14%, followed by the U.K. at 9.1%, China 8.1%, Spain 7.6% and Ireland 5.5%. All other countries make up less than 3% of the portfolio.The fund prefers to concentrate its holdings in 30 to 40 positions. The typical global fund has more than three times as many. "We know what we own, and why own it" is one of the fund's mantras.So is finding value.Look at the top 10 holdings and the active equity investor will recognize plenty of names. At the top is integrated Level 3 Communications (LVLT), followed by wireless telecom play T-Mobile USA (TMUS). Candy, chocolate and cheese maker Mondelez (MDLZ), Chinese internet search giant Baidu (BIDU) and global banking franchise Citigroup (C) also make up part of the top 10."We are global value investors," says Vinson Walden, according to Thornburg.com. "We use a value-based research process to identify quality businesses at attractive prices around the world."Broomfield, Colo.-based Level 3 sells network access to telecom providers. At about 57, shares trade a hefty 28 times fiscal year 2016 earnings. However, Level 3's peak P-E ratio over the past five years is 70.Baidu, one of the hottest Chinese ADRs in the U.S. following the market bottom in 2009, also does not seem cheap. At 173, the stock trades 30 times its FY 2016 earnings of $5.66 a share. However, Wall Street sees earnings rising to $7.54 a share by 2018 after a slight dip in 2017.Like Thornburg Global Opportunities, the $4.1 billion Oppenheimer Global Opportunities carries a heavy weighting on the U.S., which makes up 47.6% of the entire fund as of Jan. 31. Next is the U.K. at 12.6%. But Oppenheimer differs from Thornburg in its next three largest weightings: Denmark at 8.5%, Germany 8.5% and Japan 6.0%.One major Oppenheimer holding that hails from Denmark is the biotech Genmab, the fourth-largest holding in the fund with a 2.9% weighting as of Jan. 31. Genmab develops therapies for cancer and other diseases including multiple sclerosis.According to the global equities database of William O'Neil + Co., Genmab turned profitable in 2012, earning 2.20 Danish krone per share. Earnings have risen every year since then and are up nearly 10-fold to 19.83 krone a share in 2016.The stock broke out of a long cup with handle base at 257.10 krone in the final week of October in 2014. Genmab rose 15 weeks in a row before cooling off and forming a new cup-with-handle pattern from July to October 2015. Genmab eventually broke out again and is now near 1,443.Other top holdings in the Oppenheimer fund include U.S.-based Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) at a 5.2% weighting, laser and precision optical device maker Coherent (COHR) at 3.6% and semiconductor manufacturing equipment titan Applied Materials (AMAT) at 1.7%.Meanwhile, the $2.2 billion Oakmark Global Select fund has juiced its returns partly due to some timely and big bets on the banks and other financial institutions. Bank of America (BAC) is the biggest investment, taking up 6.8% of the fund's assets as of Dec. 31, 2016.Credit Suisse (CS) is also a hefty holding at 5.8%, followed by the insurance giant American International Group (AIG) at 5.5% and Citigroup (C) at 5.1%. Together, those four stocks make up nearly a quarter of the fund.Switzerland-based Credit Suisse and New York-based Citi clearly have operations around the world and are known as a banker to corporations and large institutions as well as high net worth individuals. But Citi is also a play on the rising middle class across many emerging market economies. According to its Q4 2016 report, Citigroup posted $3.36 billion in adjusted revenue from Asia, $2.65 billion from the EMEA region (Europe, Middle East, Africa) and $2.23 billion from Latin America. Together, they equaled $8.24 billion, or 50% of total adjusted revenue of $16.36 billion.RELATED:Top Global Mutual Funds: Why India Mattered In The 2016 Big WinnersHow To Invest: Top Global Stocks Trading In The U.S. TodayHow To Trade Index ETFs: Making Money With IBD's Results-Proven Stock Market Timing Mechanism

After rebuffing Kraft Heinz's (KHC) advances last week, making headlines, Unilever (UN) said it is conducting a "comprehensive review of options available to accelerate delivery of value for the benefit of our shareholders.""The events of the last week have highlighted the need to capture more quickly the value we see in Unilever," said the statement. "We expect the review to be completed by early April, after which we will communicate further."Unilever shares rose 3.7% to 46.75 at the close on the stock market today. It tumbled 7.6% on Tuesday, but lost only half of Friday's Kraft-fueled gain. The company, whose broad consumer products portfolio includes Axe, Dove and Lipton and others brands, also trades as Unilever PLC (UL).Kraft Heinz shares retreated 1.6% to 93.36 at the close.The major food conglomerate said Friday that it had pitched a $50-a-share takeover offer worth $143 billion, which Unilever had rejected. By Sunday, the ketchup and Kool-Aid maker said it had "amicably" given up its pursuit.IBD'S TAKE: Food-stock chatter abounds. Get caught up on what's happening in the space.Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), a major shareholder in Kraft Heinz along with cost-cutting specialist 3G Capital, is known to prefer "friendly" acquisitions.Berkshire Hathaway edged up 0.4% to 169.61.Meanwhile, Colgate (CL) shares were up 0.4% to 73.49 at the close. The stock had risen 6% in the prior two sessions as the consumer products firm has been tossed about as a potential new target for Kraft Heinz or even Unilever.Mondelez International (MDLZ) fell 0.7% to 44.65. Mondelez, which announced a snacks products shake-up on Tuesday, is another possible Kraft target.RELATED:Mondelez Grows Organically As Investors Salivate Over Merger BuzzKraft Heinz, Unilever Fall After Bid Nixed, But Deal Buzz ContinuesKraft Heinz's Unilever Bid Lifts Clorox, Colgate, Kimberly-Clark, P&G

While merger discussions roil the food industry, Mondelez International (MDLZ) is doing its best to increase sales on its own.The company is introducing a new line of crackers and snack bars made without artificial ingredients and GMOs, and it's revamping some of its existing products to better appeal to millennials. The rollout is Mondelez's biggest since it was created by splitting with Kraft Foods in 2012.The maker of Oreo cookies and Triscuits, which has posted declining sales the past three years, is renovating its portfolio as consumers increasingly demand less-processed snacks. The new products, called Vea, were developed in-house by a "startup" team — a sign the food giant is trying to be more entrepreneurial.Vea arrives as traditional packaged-food companies have been gobbling up upstart brands in response to the changing tastes, and as Kraft Heinz's (KHC) freshly abandoned courtship of Unilever (UL) (UN) raises the prospect of bigger realignments in the industry.IBD'S TAKE: Mondelez shares rose sharply Tuesday, retaking their 50-day line on revived hopes that Kraft or another company might make a takeover bid. Mondelez has generated profit growth even as revenue falls, much like Kraft and some of its peers. How long can the snacks giant rely on cost cuts and other margin-boosting moves without topline growth?Tim Cofer, Mondelez's chief growth officer, said the Deerfield, Ill.-based company considered making an acquisition but ultimately decided to develop the new food line itself."There was nothing out there that hit this space as well as what we developed," he said. Shares ended the day up nearly 6% to 44.97.The Vea products are slated to reach shelves across the U.S. in July, and they will eventually be expanded to overseas markets — where the company generates most of its revenue. Mondelez also is removing genetically modified organisms from Triscuits and will tout that the crackers are made from just three ingredients.Mondelez's profit margins have lagged behind competitors, and the company is under activist pressure to improve its performance. Chief Executive Irene Rosenfeld has been cutting costs to boost results, but the strong dollar has battered the company, which generates more than 70% of its sales outside North America.Last year, Mondelez made a failed bid for Hershey (HSY), an attempt to crack the U.S. chocolate market. The merger approach was also seen as a defensive move: By bulking up, Mondelez would be less of a takeover target itself.Kraft Heinz, which was formed when Kraft Foods merged with Heinz in 2015, made a $143 billion takeover bid for Unilever last week, but formally pulled the offer after it was rejected. Mondelez has been seen as a possible target of Kraft Heinz as well.Ultimately, companies have to figure out a way to increase sales if they want to keep investors happy, said Asit Sharma, an analyst at the Motley Fool."Investors understand that cost-cutting and productivity initiatives have a limited shelf-life in boosting earnings," he said. "Sooner or later, revenue growth will be top of mind for investors."RELATED:Kraft Heinz, Unilever Fall After Bid Nixed, But Deal Buzz Continues

Shares of Kraft Heinz (KHC) fell nearly 2% Tuesday afternoon after the food giant "amicably agreed to withdraw" its $143 billion, $50-a-share proposal to merge with consumer goods conglomerate Unilever (UN), but deal buzz continued to support the two giants as well as other food and consumer product makers."Unilever and Kraft Heinz hold each other in high regard," said the Sunday release. "Kraft Heinz has the utmost respect for the culture, strategy and leadership of Unilever."The joint statement from Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB)-backed Kraft Heinz and Unilever spurred a 180-degree shift from Friday's market action, in which Kraft Heinz's stock spiked 10.7% on public confirmation of the bid. Friday's statement from Kraft Heinz had also indicated that it would continue to pursue the parent company of Dove and Vaseline, despite its initial rejection of the offer. Shares ended the day off 1.78 to 94.87.Unilever shares plunged nearly 8% to 45.09 on the stock market today after soaring 15.3% Friday. The company, which trades as both Unilever NV and Unilever PLC (UL) said last week that the proposal "fundamentally undervalues" the company and provides no financial or strategic merit for Unilever shareholders.The quick reversal in Kraft Heinz's intentions may stem from Warren Buffett's sentiment toward hostile takeovers. Berkshire Hathaway "will join only with partners making friendly acquisitions," he said in his 2015 annual letter to shareholders. He acknowledged that some hostile bids are "justified.""We, though, will leave these 'opportunities' for others," he wrote. "At Berkshire, we go only where we are welcome."Berkshire Hathaway and 3G engineered the 2015 merger of Kraft and Heinz. Berkshire Class B shares were up fractionally.A Kraft Heinz-Unilever merger would have made for the second-largest food-and-drink company in the world, according to Bloomberg data, bringing together brands such as Oscar Mayer and Planters and Lipton and Hellmann's. The combination of Kraft and Heinz two years ago created the fifth largest.While Kraft and Unilever retreated Tuesday, they kept a good share of Monday's gains on speculation that industry consolidation could still happen.Other consumer goods heavyweights were on the move Tuesday as speculation circulated that Kraft Heinz might have another acquisition target in mind. Colgate Palmolive (CL) was up 1.2%. Clorox (CLX) ticked up 0.9%. Procter & Gamble (PG) edged 0.5%. Kimberly-Clark (KMB) inched up 1.2%.Colgate, Clorox and Kimberly-Clark posted big gains Friday on the initial Kraft-Unilever news. Dow component P&G inched up to a 2-year high Friday after surging earlier in the week on news that activist investor Trian Fund Management had taken a $3.5 billion stake.Meanwhile, Mondelez International (MDLZ) was up 4.9% as it announced an overhaul of its snack line, while General Mills (GIS) added 2.8%.
